best.why: Section I builds through historical parallels (Gutenberg, photography) with measured, declarative confidence. C is the only version that continues that exact structural move — Impressionists, Fauves — without breaking stride. 'Nail it to our door' carries a Luther echo that fits a manifesto. The rhythm stays tight and controlled; nothing showboats. It reads like the same voice wrote both sections.

worst.why: The spit/lick opening lurches into aggression that Section I never establishes. 'And you still don't' is combative where the manifesto is declarative — it picks a fight with the reader instead of recruiting them. The paragraph order (cut, then coat) inverts the natural logic and loses momentum.

must_survive_line: A Slopist does not sign a prompt. A Slopist signs the cut.
